Question_1.Context: The study focused on the pharmaceutical efficacy of Res and Res/CD on different cell cultures.
Question_1.Question: What is the abbreviation for Cyclodextrins used in the study?

Question_2.Context: The study involved the modification of culture dishes using plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition.
Question_2.Question: What technique was used to modify the surface of culture dishes in the study?
Question_2.Source: Surface modification of polystyrene Petri dishes via plasma polymerization Plasma modification experiments were conducted using the precursor octamethyl-3,5-bis(trimethylsiloxyl) tetrasiloxane (OMBTSTS) in a PECVD system.

Question_3.Context: The study investigated the growth of HeLa cell spheroids on modified culture dishes.
Question_3.Question: What was the optimal monomer for enhancing surface construction in spheroid formation?
Question_3.Source: Table 1 summarizes that OMBTSTS is an optimal monomer for enhancing surface construction, resulting in improved spheroid formation and the decreased proliferation of monolayered (2D) cells.

Question_4.Context: The study examined the water contact angle of the treated surfaces.
Question_4.Question: What does WCA stand for in the context of the study?
Question_4.Source: Water contact angle measurement The fixed-drop method (FM40 Easy Drop; KRUS GmbH, Germany) was used to measure WCA.

Question_5.Context: The study involved the characterization of ppOMBTSTS and ppTMSS surface coatings.
Question_5.Question: What does FTIR stand for in the context of the study?
Question_5.Source: FTIR spectroscopy (Vertex 70, Bruker, USA) was performed using the attenuated total reflectance technique.

Question_6.Context: The study examined the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements of the samples.
Question_6.Question: What technique was used to perform XPS analysis in the study?
Question_6.Source: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurement A photoelectron spectrometer (AXIS Supra, Kratos, UK) with monochromatic Al Kα X-ray sources at 1486.6 eV was used to perform XPS analysis.

Question_7.Context: The study focused on the generation of spheroids using different precursor types.
Question_7.Question: What was the carrier gas flow rate optimized for 3D spheroid formation?
Question_7.Source: Moreover, our data revealed that a lower carrier flow rate was more conducive to spheroid generation than a higher flow rate (60 vs. 90 SCCM) (Table 1).

Question_8.Context: The study investigated the apoptosis of HeLa cell spheroids.
Question_8.Question: What was used to measure caspase-3 activity in the HeLa cell spheroids?
Question_8.Source: To measure caspase-3 activity, HeLa cell spheroids were treated with various reagents mentioned in the Materials and Methods sections. FITC fluorescent intensity (excitation wavelength: 485 nm, emission wavelength: 525 nm) indicates caspase-3 activity.

Question_9.Context: The study examined the viability of cells treated with Res and Res/CD.
Question_9.Question: What was used to measure the viability of cells treated with Res and Res/CD?
Question_9.Source: To assess cell viability, cells were treated with 0–100 μM Res (Sigma- Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) or Res/CD and cobalt chlo- ride (CoCl2, Sigma-Aldrich) for 24 h.

Question_10.Context: The study focused on the construction of 3D spheroids for drug evaluation.
Question_10.Question: What was the main conclusion drawn from the study regarding the efficacy of Res/CD on tumor spheroids?
Question_10.A: Res/CD selectively induced necroptosis in tumor spheroids.
Question_10.B: Res/CD was not effective in inducing cell death.
Question_10.C: Res was more effective than Res/CD in inducing apoptosis.
Question_10.D: Res/CD had no impact on 3D spheroids.
Question_10.Source: Furthermore, this study reveals that non-toxic concentrations of Res/ CD selectively induce necroptosis in tumor spheroids, as opposed to 2D cancer cells.
